@OnlyCFO I agree with this except it‚Äôs more like they will plan for 3x growth but only grow 0.5x, thereby exploding burn multiple.
Meaning that: Given economic headwinds, 2x YoY growth over the next year will be as impressive (or more) as growing 3x last year, assuming a reasonable burn multiple.
2x is the new 3x.
To be clear, this is not a critique of Salesforce (which is one of the best-managed SaaS companies), it‚Äôs a commentary on economic conditions.

This could become a vicious cycle:

Layoffs ‚Äî> Seat Contraction ‚Äî> Sales Slowdown ‚Äî> Cut Costs ‚Äî> Layoffs

Repeat.

One of the ways the media tries to minimize the FTX fraud is to put it in the ‚Äúcrypto is sketchy‚Äù bucket. Actually the issue is the misappropriation of customer deposits on an exchange. If FTX had been trading pork bellies, orange juice or silver, the crime would be the same. https://t.co/D9roMdZ9SD

Describing what happened as ‚Äúa run on the bank‚Äù is deceptive since FTX was not a bank. Banks have the right to lend customer deposits; FTX did not. Customers kept those deposits for one purpose only: to trade. Appropriating those funds crossed the brightest of all red lines.

30. Watch @mtaibbi for the next installment.

29. We're just getting started on our reporting. Documents cannot tell the whole story here. A big thank you to everyone who has spoken to us so far. If you are a current or former Twitter employee, we'd love to hear from you. Please write to: tips@thefp.com
28. The authors have broad and expanding access to Twitter‚Äôs files. The only condition we agreed to was that the material would first be published on Twitter.

27. There is more to come on this story, which was reported by @abigailshrier @shellenbergermd @nelliebowles @isaacgrafstein and the team The Free Press @thefp. 

Keep up with this unfolding story here and at our brand new website: https://t.co/qYaBJzKcZj.

26. He added: ‚ÄúWe got Jack on board with implementing this for civic integrity in the near term, but we‚Äôre going to need to make a more robust case to get this into our repertoire of policy remediations ‚Äì especially for other policy domains.‚Äù

25. Roth wrote: ‚ÄúThe hypothesis underlying much of what we‚Äôve implemented is that if exposure to, e.g., misinformation directly causes harm, we should use remediations that reduce exposure, and limiting the spread/virality of content is a good way to do that.‚Äù

24. Six days later, in a direct message with an employee on the Health, Misinformation, Privacy, and Identity research team, Roth requested more research to support expanding ‚Äúnon-removal policy interventions like disabling engagements and deamplification/visibility filtering.‚Äù https://t.co/lqiJapHjct

23. In internal Slack messages, Twitter employees spoke of using technicalities to restrict the visibility of tweets and subjects. Here‚Äôs Yoel Roth, Twitter‚Äôs then Global Head of Trust & Safety, in a direct message to a colleague in early 2021: https://t.co/Li7HDZJtIJ

22. When Raichik told Twitter that her address had been disseminated she says Twitter Support responded with this message: "We reviewed the reported content, and didn't find it to be in violation of the Twitter rules." No action was taken. The doxxing tweet is still up. https://t.co/tUeaBP1bS4
21. Compare this to what happened when Raichik herself was doxxed on November 21, 2022. A photo of her home with her address was posted in a tweet that has garnered more than 10,000 likes.

20. The committee justified her suspensions internally by claiming her posts encouraged online harassment of ‚Äúhospitals and medical providers‚Äù by insinuating ‚Äúthat gender-affirming healthcare is equivalent to child abuse or grooming.‚Äù

19. But in an internal SIP-PES memo from October 2022, after her seventh suspension, the committee acknowledged that ‚ÄúLTT has not directly engaged in behavior violative of the Hateful Conduct policy." See here: https://t.co/d9FGhrnQFE
18. Twitter repeatedly informed Raichik that she had been suspended for violating Twitter‚Äôs policy against ‚Äúhateful conduct.‚Äù

17. The account‚Äîwhich Chaya Raichik began in November 2020 and now boasts over 1.4 million followers‚Äîwas subjected to six suspensions in 2022 alone, Raichik says. Each time, Raichik was blocked from posting for as long as a week.

16. One of the accounts that rose to this level of scrutiny was @libsoftiktok‚Äîan account that was on the ‚ÄúTrends Blacklist‚Äù and was designated as ‚ÄúDo Not Take Action on User Without Consulting With SIP-PES.‚Äù https://t.co/Vjo6YxYbxT

15. This is where the biggest, most politically sensitive decisions got made. ‚ÄúThink high follower account, controversial,‚Äù another Twitter employee told us. For these ‚Äúthere would be no ticket or anything.‚Äù
14. This secret group included Head of Legal, Policy, and Trust (Vijaya Gadde), the Global Head of Trust & Safety (Yoel Roth), subsequent CEOs Jack Dorsey and Parag Agrawal, and others.

13. But there existed a level beyond official ticketing, beyond the rank-and-file moderators following the company‚Äôs policy on paper. That is the ‚ÄúSite Integrity Policy, Policy Escalation Support,‚Äù known as ‚ÄúSIP-PES.‚Äù
12. The group that decided whether to limit the reach of certain users was the Strategic Response Team - Global Escalation Team, or SRT-GET. It often handled up to 200 "cases" a day.

11. ‚ÄúWe control visibility quite a bit. And we control the amplification of your content quite a bit. And normal people do not know how much we do,‚Äù one Twitter engineer told us. Two additional Twitter employees confirmed.
10. All without users‚Äô knowledge.

9. ‚ÄúVF‚Äù refers to Twitter‚Äôs control over user visibility. It used VF to block searches of individual users; to limit the scope of a particular tweet‚Äôs discoverability; to block select users‚Äô posts from ever appearing on the ‚Äútrending‚Äù page; and from inclusion in hashtag searches.
8. ‚ÄúThink about visibility filtering as being a way for us to suppress what people see to different levels. It‚Äôs a very powerful tool,‚Äù one senior Twitter employee told us.
7. What many people call ‚Äúshadow banning,‚Äù Twitter executives and employees call ‚ÄúVisibility Filtering‚Äù or ‚ÄúVF.‚Äù Multiple high-level sources confirmed its meaning.

6. Twitter denied that it does such things. In 2018, Twitter's Vijaya Gadde (then Head of Legal Policy and Trust) and Kayvon Beykpour (Head of Product) said: ‚ÄúWe do not shadow ban.‚Äù They added: ‚ÄúAnd we certainly don‚Äôt shadow ban based on political viewpoints or ideology.‚Äù
5. Twitter set the account of conservative activist Charlie Kirk (@charliekirk11) to ‚ÄúDo Not Amplify.‚Äù https://t.co/dOyQIVdsW2
4. Or consider the popular right-wing talk show host, Dan Bongino (@dbongino), who at one point was slapped with a ‚ÄúSearch Blacklist.‚Äù https://t.co/AdOK8xLu9v

3. Take, for example, Stanford‚Äôs Dr. Jay Bhattacharya (@DrJBhattacharya) who argued that Covid lockdowns would harm children. Twitter secretly placed him on a ‚ÄúTrends Blacklist,‚Äù which prevented his tweets from trending. https://t.co/qTW22Zh691
2. Twitter once had a mission ‚Äúto give everyone the power to create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.‚Äù Along the way, barriers nevertheless were erected.

1. A new #TwitterFiles investigation reveals that teams of Twitter employees build blacklists, prevent disfavored tweets from trending, and actively limit the visibility of entire accounts or even trending topics‚Äîall in secret, without informing users.

Early transplant preferred. But for selected standard risk patients depending on preference, delayed is also OK. Maintenance varies by risk stratification. https://t.co/pfV83LhB5R

My thoughts on SMM were shaped and influenced years ago through conversations with Drs. Kyle, San Miguel, Merlini, Landgren, Mateos, Lonial, Kumar, Durie, Paiva, Dimopoulos, and many others. 

So glad to see continued progress.

I must say many leaders in the field share the same vision and commitment with regards to SMM. And are doing a range of studies and trials in this regard, especially @IreneGhobrial and @DrOlaLandgren 

The full spectrum of studies is what it will take to solve this puzzle.

We have the same vision and goal. For me it was inspired by @DeVitaDoctor and how he approached cure in Hodgkin lymphoma: Cure means fixed duration therapy, stop treatment, the disease never ever comes back in a reasonable proportion of patients.  

That‚Äôs what we are going for.
RT @chadinabhan: I love the fact that this is a fixed duration study and explores MRD. I believe curing a disease requires eradication at t‚Ä¶

@chadinabhan @ASH_hematology Yes. Cure means fixed duration therapy, stop treatment, the disease never ever comes back in a reasonable proportion of patients.  

That‚Äôs what we are going for.

This is a multi decade vision. I‚Äôm glad the trials were started and we already have years of follow up. 

Congrats to @mvmateos and @myelomaMD for overcoming numerous obstacles to get us to this point.

There will be successor trials similar to CESAR and ASCENT. If and when the results look very promising the next step would be to compare the winning regimen from one of the Cure trials to whatever is standard of care at the time in a randomized trial.

It will be a decade or two to determine whether we are successful. The natural history of high risk SMM with observation or mild therapy is known. The goal with the Cure trials is to see if there is a plateau in disease free survival that‚Äôs enduring & far beyond what‚Äôs expected.

These trials are part of a planned series of trials investigating whether the incurability of myeloma is related to the fact that we have traditionally started effective therapy only after the disease has spread and mutated to the point where it is no longer curable.

Updated results from the 1st Cure trial, GEM-CESAR led by @mvmateos is also being presented at #ASH22

https://t.co/RAdqP5Dfl0

At #ASH22 my colleague @myelomaMD will present the initial results of the ASCENT trial, aka the 2nd Cure trial to test the hypothesis whether myeloma can be cured if highly active combination therapy is given early at the smoldering myeloma stage. https://t.co/9fvVoPvwBM https://t.co/GXdvY4J72z

@wangyub As always use judgment. If you have 40% bone marrow PCs and the only MDE is 2 focal lesions on MRI, that‚Äôs likely MM and you wouldn‚Äôt need to biopsy or wait. If you have only 12% PCs the you may want to biopsy or wait and repeat imaging. Also depends on FLC level and ratio.

@wangyub The criteria are very specific on how to use the MRI. If that‚Äôs the only MDE you need bone marrow with >=10% clonal plasma cells and 2 or more definite focal lesions on MRI at least 5mm in size. If in doubt wait 3-6 months and repeat. Diffuse abnormalities or signal is not MDE.

For those interested the paper which was previously the most cited paper ever in myeloma was the 1975 Durie Salmon staging system with 3940 citations.  

(Citations as captured in Google Scholar)

12/ This is all thanks & credit to IMWG & coauthors. Jesus San Miguel, Giampaolo Merlini, Ken Anderson, Bob Kyle. Many are on Twitter: @thanosdimop @mvmateos @myelomaMD @BrianDurieMD @SagarLonialMD @szusmani @ADispenzieri @sykristinsson @DrOlaLandgren @mbeksac56 @BrunoPaiva_UNAV https://t.co/dmqkEouveg

11/ There‚Äôs a lot more in this paper. The authors worked on many drafts to ensure we got it right and had consensus. 

I have never worked on a paper where every single sentence has so much importance and meaning as in this paper.
10/ CRAB features do not need to be symptomatic.

9/ Infections, suppression of uninvolved immunoglobulins are not considered myeloma defining events. Too non specific. Patients must meet one of the 7 myeloma defining events defined in the criteria to be considered as having myeloma.
8/ Presence of clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow biopsy is not needed for diagnosis of myeloma. Presence of a biopsy proven plasmacytoma with another myeloma defining event is sufficient.

7/ Presence of serum or urine M protein is not necessary for myeloma diagnosis. Non secretory myeloma is myeloma and treated as such. It‚Äôs not a separate disease. It‚Äôs more of a description, and it‚Äôs understood that monitoring will be different in such patients.

6/ Only light chain cast nephropathy qualifies as a myeloma defining renal event. All other renal lesions attributable to monoclonal protein are considered unique disorders and do not automatically mean malignancy or meet the criteria for myeloma diagnosis.

5/ Clarification and recommendations for   advanced imaging (CT, PET-CT ) to detect lytic bone lesions. 

To distinguish MM from SMM, MRI imaging may be needed.
4/ MGUS was formally classified into 3 types with specific diagnostic criteria outlined for each. #ASH22 #MedTwitter https://t.co/f7Cjf06vM3
3/ We simultaneously updated the diagnostic criteria for related plasma cell disorders including MGUS, SMM, and solitary plasmacytoma. https://t.co/D9l07jzAP6

2/ The paradigm shifting  change was including 3 biomarkers that were associated with 80% or greater probability of progression within 2 years as myeloma defining events on top of CRAB. 

>100 myeloma experts gave input for the paper. #ASH22 #MedTwitter https://t.co/ZoIwF4QgOZ

Just in time for #ASH22

The IMWG updated diagnostic criteria for myeloma & related disorders has just become the most cited myeloma paper ever. @TheLancetOncol #MedTwitter https://t.co/61ohPFLtGi

"content" and "media" may end as terms, as we simply enjoy personalized experiences, not productize or distribute uniform consumables. centralized production for many is replaced by decentralized production for each individual human. should be fun.

community will likely still matter (shared content experiences), but not in its current form. perhaps we each experience a storyline in a global story/movie/game, or tweak segments of a master song to our own preferences (more drum solos!).. but then that too may feel arcane..

this doesn't seem feasible today but as AI models train on "emotion", they may move away from objective (extended) mimicry to producing something that starts to feel novel, perhaps more novel than human creators, and then things will change fast..

everyone will enjoy their own personalized movie, music, book, news article, video game experience. it may seem silly one day that many humans listened to the same piece of music, watched the same movie, read the same book...
it seems more likely that AI won't replace the creator in the traditional model but rather will become the personalized content creator for each individual...
i think what some predictors have wrong about generative AI is the expectation that it will create content in its current one-to-many form - one movie, one piece of music, a book, consumed by many...

but the past few years have shown us that authority-driven journalism won't be the standard going forward. 

i hope, and expect, that the open internet, and whatever platforms enable fact-finding, discovery, and truth, will win out over the sensational, the moderated, the closed
so, eventually all content may find its way to distributed systems. esp if governments begin excessively intervening in the content moderation schema of platforms.
whether open platforms will work in a centralized or decentralized model, i don't know. shareholders may eventually have to kowtow to regulatory bodies.

ML-based tagging, as has been done so well at youtube, can create a framework for making this better experience; active filtering using those tags should required by the reader in order to engage the service.

by shifting responsibility to the reader, to clearly state what they do, and do not, want to see and read, and revealing to them what other readers "think" about particular content, perhaps we can engage people to think differently and have a more rounded discourse.

i believe that platforms must create tools that shift responsibility from the citizen journalist (no policing of content) to the reader - with strong tools for filtering, preference, and influence selection being the core offering of the platform. not viral engagement.

but yes, open platforms can quickly devolve into Lord of the Flies.. the desire for sensational content and the mechanism of groupthink can quickly make the untrue the accepted truth. how to avoid this?
and through citizen journalism, perhaps, the truth can be revealed better than it may be through the service of a handful of trusted moderators who are increasingly inclined to the sensational.

and this is why more open platforms are so important - they offer a chance for any citizen of the service to say, or show, what they see, hear, feel without the approval of the journalist, or a moderator.
since COVID, some of what was chastised as conspiracy theory, fringe thinking, and fake news, at the time, turned out to be, maybe, just a little bit right.

the unaffiliated individual reporting some as-yet unseen fact, and the citizenry, en masse, discovering truth, together, IS the new media. 

this is the manifestation of the promise of the open internet. and it is vital.

the journalistic void seems to have been, and is being, filled by citizen journalism - from internet sleuths, cell phone videographers, home office analysts, sharing their fact-finding across twitter, youtube, discord and reddit..

sensational stories are simply better business than the boring truth. 

(side note: props to @rahul_ligma_ for superb trolling!)

today, the truth doesn't matter as much as the sensational. we all see this - modern mass media "journalism" is simply oriented around sensationalism. the topics, theses, content need to excite some emotion or it won't find a viewer and, thus, can't become relevant "news"...

the reporting of "fired twitter employees" (which turned out to be pranksters) was neither verified nor supported by other investigated facts. "journalists" simply repeated untruths across live media. why? because it was sensational...
what defines a "journalist" today? does a person repeating what someone else said, without taking steps to verify their statement, qualify? ...

for these reasons, and others (driven by various other science/eng advances), i am optimistic about mankind's ability to survive and thrive through the end of this century and well into the next, at which point, it appears far more than we can imagine today may become possible..

what would our species pursue with abundant cheap heavy elements? that's not clear today, but new technologies would generally be more accessible/feasible; interstellar travel would certainly be easier (atoms on a star ship could be recycled/converted).

entire industries in the 22nd century could be built around terrestrial nucleosynthesis. prices would be driven down on anything "rare" today, and operators of these next-gen commodity-producing systems could sit at the helm of new economies.

rare would become abundant. this notion of "terrestrial nucleosynthesis" hasn't been discussed much in the context of plasma fusion systems but to me represents one of the greatest next-gen unlocks after abundant free energy.

plasma fusion systems should eventually get denser, hotter, more energetic, yielding an ability to not just generate electricity, but to drive collisions of small particles into bigger and bigger nuclei... we could eventually "synthesize" heavy elements here on Earth!

"rare earth elements" (used in batteries & electronics) are very hard to find/mine; phosphorus (a fertilizer critical to growing all our crops on Earth) will be fully mined out of Earth's crust in ~100 years. etc
however, in a post-plasma fusion world, things could be different..

produced from the dense energy inside stars that exploded billions of years before the formation of Earth (and were part of our planet's formation), we've always assumed heavier elements here on Earth were fixed natural resources - we can't just make more

in stars, over time, as protons and neutrons and bigger nuclei collide with each other under extreme energy and pressure, bigger and bigger nuclei are formed - all heavier elements (heavier than hydrogen) are formed this way. carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, iron, lithium, nedoymium etc

as we move past the 21st century and plasma fusion, like all technologies, becomes faster, cheaper, smaller, better, its application set will expand beyond its original obvious purpose. to what? well, remember, plasma fusion is fundamentally the system of stars...

we tend to think about new technologies linearly.. their obvious application solving a problem directly in front of us. but more often than not, the value realized from new tech is its utilization across novel applications.

Note: This is my view and not a recommendation. For important additional info, see Akili‚Äôs press release: https://t.co/IRunUdLCm3

Up next: Q4 commercial launch of Akili‚Äôs first product, EndeavorRx

Later: potentially bringing EndeavorRx to broader ADHD populations, and expanding to new disease areas (depression, autism, MS, Covid brain fog, etc.) /7

This can be a great new option for many families. It significantly broadens access and is a viable treatment option, especially with many parents hesitant to put their kids on drugs (like a Schedule II controlled substance) which can have limiting side effects themselves /6

Like working out a specific muscle at the gym, EndeavorRx is designed to target key neural systems in the brain related to attention. But because it‚Äôs software, the treatment can adapt the gameplay in real-time to maintain a consistent level of difficulty for each patient /5

Their first product (EndeavorRx) will launch in Q4. It‚Äôs a first-of-its-kind, FDA-cleared, doctor-prescribed video game designed to treat inattention in pediatric ADHD, one of the most prevalent cognitive impairments among kids today /4

Full indication: https://t.co/i1exC2DfE1

Akili has pioneered an entirely new category of medicine designed to directly and safely target these issues in the brain.

Based on 10+ yrs of research and rigorous clinical tests, they combine cog. science & patented tech to deliver medicine via software on a phone or tablet /3

Today there are limited options & access to treat the cognitive issues (memory/attention/etc) associated with diseases like depression, autism, ADHD.

Treatments like therapy & pills may help mood, but don‚Äôt target cognition - which can be just as debilitating to daily life /2

I‚Äôm proud to share that $DNAA has successfully completed its deal to bring @AkiliLabs public. I am investing $100M in @EddieMartucci & the Akili team to address the growing and worsening mental health crisis in the U.S. /1

@IdiotTracker So when I ask for preop "clearance," it's because my anesthesiologist gestalt says that I need more information to do a case safely.

It's weird how willing people are to be super cavalier about risks that *other people* should be willing to take.

@DruvBhagavan I have found that the idea that people are somehow not as sick in PP to be absolute nonsense, although that would be true in some specific outpatient practices.  We do tend to see a little less of the more "exotic" chronic pathologies. 4/

@DruvBhagavan While, again, practices vary, I have not seen the wild production pressure that I hear academic people talk about being rampant in PP, and I would say that it's pretty similar between my academic husband and his colleague and my practice. 3/

@DruvBhagavan Obviously academic folk as a group spend more time on research that PP people, although there are some of us in PP who do quite a lot of "scholarly activity" and some academics who don't do a ton. 2/

@DruvBhagavan I think that this is a little bit of a tough question to answer, since there is a very wide range in practice among both academic and private practices, but broadly I would say that there is less difference than is generally assumed. 1/

Joe Klande‚Ä¶

If there‚Äôs one takeaway, it‚Äôs this: What matters most in platform governance is how decisions get made. You can armchair quarterback specific choices and mistakes all day. But the real work is figuring out how to make principled decisions when all you have are bad options.

Grateful for the chance to sit down with @karaswisher and talk about the last few years in Trust & Safety at Twitter, warts and all. 

The headlines only scratch the surface of the conversation. 

Apple Podcasts: https://t.co/kDFtUNeuZI
Spotify: https://t.co/gRxGNJVJRG

@EmilyGorcenski Hi Emily - I stopped engaging because I don‚Äôt think I can say anything to help here. My long-deleted LiveJournal entries from 2008 don‚Äôt represent who I am today, what my beliefs are today, or what I work towards every day. I‚Äôm deeply sorry.
@EmilyGorcenski It isn‚Äôt.

@EmilyGorcenski Ok. I‚Äôm pretty steeped in queer history, and my recollection is different. But I apologize if those tweets caused hurt for you or anyone else; that was not my intent. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm the enemy here.

@EmilyGorcenski The acceptability of that term has changed a lot since I posted those tweets a decade ago. I wouldn‚Äôt use that word now. While at Twitter, I did everything within my power to fight to protect folks, including trans people. The work is never done and I wish I could have done more.

@jilliancyork I linked to one of your pieces in an original draft (https://t.co/hVWrlToeHv) - ended up not making it into the final version, unfortunately. Your book is a big inspiration and does a much better and deeper job with a lot of the influences here than I could in an op-ed.

Last week, I made the decision to leave my role leading Trust & Safety at Twitter.

Today, I'm sharing a few thoughts about what comes next for the site. https://t.co/QPAQR6zpqU
@timothyjgraham @elonmusk I assume the source for this is public API data? If so, it's worth noting that much of what we're doing re: restricting reach is not reflected in the APIs (at the moment).

Those steps take away many of the gratifications of the trolling here. Bans are frustrating and take work (and resources) to try to circumvent; visibility filtering deprives trolls of the attention and reach they're trying to get.
@mgoldstein Important point! I'll try to share a breakdown that gets into this more specifically soon. Obviously that surface matters too; just not parsed out in this graph.

Update on our efforts to combat hateful conduct: We've not only mitigated the recent surge in harmful behavior, but have reduced impressions on this content in Search by ~95% relative to even prior baseline levels. We're continuing our work to make Twitter safer every day. https://t.co/lK5fMRWCGb https://t.co/g4X6ue0f8W
@GoAngelo I wouldn't agree with that characterization of what I said. More proportionate enforcement for less severe harms doesn't mean reducing the amount of moderation we do.

@JasonAbbruzzese This is our vision with the Twitter Moderation Research Consortium (https://t.co/V8cQWO4gR3) ‚Äî and we already offer leading access, including free access for academics, to all public tweets via our developer APIs (https://t.co/D4qVrSj0WG).

@pwnallthethings Got it - I wasn‚Äôt clear you meant compromise after Blue badging. Agree. There‚Äôs a longer discussion to have about our historical reluctance to automatically lock down notable accounts when we detect suspicious logins; that‚Äôs likely less of a concern for Blue Verification.

@pwnallthethings This assumes we have no post-verification checks or investigations. Sure, it‚Äôs a threat vector. It‚Äôs also a mitigable one that imposes durable costs on the adversary when caught and shut down. Costs I estimate are higher than the existing buy-a-hacked-blue-check situation.

@pwnallthethings Not sure I agree. It‚Äôs not just $8 (in the initial implementation): it‚Äôs $8, and a valid credit card that doesn‚Äôt have fraud flags, and an Apple ID that doesn‚Äôt have any fraud flags, and an iOS device‚Ä¶

@pwnallthethings IMO, it‚Äôs and, not or. You‚Äôre obviously right that account takeover is a major vector for a whole host of bad things. We need to invest there, and are. But we can also broadly raise the costs of spam that actually reaches people via perceived-credible accounts.
@nicoleperlroth Yep. Or, yknow, all accounts. Google does a great job nudging people towards MFA.

@RMac18 They're still under development. Not trying to evade; just don't want to tell you a bunch of stuff we end up moving away from. Our teams are actively doing threat ideation work to build a broad set of defenses.
@RMac18 That's not the only safeguard we're planning to implement. But this was already an extremely long thread, so...
No solution to identity is perfect, and we‚Äôre iterating quickly to come up with the best approach here. We appreciate all the feedback, and will share more as our work progresses.

It‚Äôs not just the $8, though ‚Äî this kind of in-app purchase requires bad actors to get through not only Twitter‚Äôs defenses, but also those of mobile device manufacturers and payment processors. That‚Äôs not impossible for a sophisticated adversary ‚Äî but it‚Äôs hard to do at scale.

Proof-of-humanness is more straightforward. Most spam-fighting is a numbers game: Your objective is to raise the costs on spammers until their losses exceed their gains. When you do that, the spammers go away, and you win. $8 per account raises the costs of spam A LOT.

For years, Verification on Twitter has been tricky because it‚Äôs a signal both of authenticity (you are who you say you are) and notability (you‚Äôre ‚Äúimportant‚Äù by some standard). 

Notability is inherently difficult to determine in a fair way globally. I support getting rid of it.

Long-term, I think we need to invest more in identity verification as a complement to proof-of-humanness. Paid Verification is a strong (not perfect) signal of humanness, which helps fight bots and spam. But that‚Äôs not the same thing as identity verification.

We‚Äôre particularly focused on the risks of impersonation of public officials in the context of the US 2022 midterm elections, and have made the decision not to launch Verification for Twitter Blue until after Election Day.

In the short term, we‚Äôll ramp up proactive review of Blue Verified accounts that show signs of impersonating another user. When we find them, we‚Äôll suspend them. See something that looks off? You can report it directly in the app.
The planned changes to Twitter Blue to make Verification more widely available raise the stakes for this kind of impersonation. Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôre going to do about it:

When Verified accounts use impersonation as a tactic ‚Äî whether for parody or not ‚Äî it creates an especially confusing experience. It‚Äôs been our long-standing practice to suspend Verified users when they do this.

Parody has long been recognized as an important form of speech, and we have clear, long-standing guidelines about how to operate parody accounts on Twitter in a non-misleading way: https://t.co/A2lHpnPX31

First, impersonation has always been banned on Twitter. Misleading profiles make Twitter worse for everyone. Last year, we banned more than half a million accounts for impersonating people and brands. https://t.co/rc8ejsISTS
Verification! Impersonation! Twitter Blue! There‚Äôs a lot going on around identity on Twitter ‚Äî let‚Äôs break down what our policies are, and some of the big questions we still need to answer‚Ä¶
@MikeIsaac @lrozen @darth Agree. A human reviewer would not designate that tweet abusive or a violation of our rules. We use a higher-recall ML approach in this context to automate. It's not perfect.

@darth @lrozen We've had this for a while, and found it can meaningfully reduce toxicity and abuse. It can also be overzealous sometimes, though. More on our blog: https://t.co/gW8khpDqxB https://t.co/HjQ37yHAMZ
@rebeccamkern No.
@sivavaid We‚Äôll check what‚Äôs going on.
@Esqueer_ I don‚Äôt want to be remembered for anything. I‚Äôm here for the same reason I have been for the last 7.5 years: doing whatever I can to make Twitter better.
@HeidiBriones Update on our child safety work coming soon. This remains a key focus area. We have zero tolerance for CSE.
@EricaJoy @MikeIsaac We haven‚Äôt done that. We‚Äôre actually expanding how we enforce those rules in the next few days.
@druwynings Those workflows rely on a different toolset than our core moderation actions.

@thehowie Maintaining human moderation isn't the full story; a core part of our approach is deploying tech to detect and take action proactively and automatically. That was the primary driver of what I wrote about in past threads re: hateful conduct.
Recruiters: My DMs are open ‚Äî I have recommendations for incredibly smart and compassionate talent that is now available.

I‚Äôll continue to share updates about our Trust & Safety work as things evolve in the days to come. Our team's mission of enforcing our policies and protecting the conversations happening on Twitter remains unchanged.

What AREN‚ÄôT we doing? In the short term, we‚Äôve had to deprioritize a few workflows ‚Äî like account access (lost password requests), and some suspension appeals. We‚Äôre working to get these back online in the days to come.

With early voting underway in the US, our efforts on election integrity ‚Äî including harmful misinformation that can suppress the vote and combatting state-backed information operations  ‚Äî remain a top priority.

More than 80% of our incoming content moderation volume was completely unaffected by this access change. The daily volume of moderation actions we take stayed steady through this period. https://t.co/rSGKtq0e3J

Last week, for security reasons, we restricted access to our internal tools for some users, including some members of my team. Most of the 2,000+ content moderators working on front-line review were not impacted, and access will be fully restored in the coming days.

Yesterday‚Äôs reduction in force affected approximately 15% of our Trust & Safety organization (as opposed to approximately 50% cuts company-wide), with our front-line moderation staff experiencing the least impact.

Here are the facts about where Twitter‚Äôs Trust & Safety and moderation capacity stands today:

tl;dr: While we said goodbye to incredibly talented friends and colleagues yesterday, our core moderation capabilities remain in place.
Tweeps: My DMs are always open to you. Tell me how I can help. üñ§ #OneTeam

@Jason @Rob1Ham It‚Äôs a tough balance. We‚Äôve tried different approaches over the years. Our latest reporting flow prioritizes getting context, because it helps us understand harm and take action more effectively. But the feedback that it‚Äôs a little lengthy is well-taken. https://t.co/91l9ONesqK
@DanLinden just setting up my twttrcontactcenter

We're hearing reports of phishing emails talking about potential changes to Verification. Be wary ‚Äî nothing has launched yet, and we aren't sending these notes. Check the sender carefully, and don't provide your credentials or payment info. https://t.co/eCpXOZM3rn
RT @elonmusk: @yoyoel Talked to civil society leaders @JGreenblattADL, @YaelEisenstat, @rashadrobinson, @JGo4Justice, @normanlschen, @Derri‚Ä¶

@SEP It‚Äôs been such a privilege getting to work with you. Thank you. üíô
@jamisonfoser The graph isn‚Äôt normalized for impressions per user. Fewer people use the latest home timeline overall.
@DocDre @Sarah_Oestreich Agree. This is what we‚Äôre working on fixing. The burden can‚Äôt be on the victims of abuse.

This is exactly what we (or any company) should be doing in the midst of a corporate transition to reduce opportunities for insider risk. We‚Äôre still enforcing our rules at scale. https://t.co/CZudS4gBqo

@chrismessina I‚Äôve always liked Instagram‚Äôs ‚Äúblock other accounts from this person‚Äù feature ‚Äî it‚Äôs a smart way to scale content controls.

We know people on Twitter use multiple accounts for lots of different reasons. So you need to be careful about overly restricting that.

@DocDre Struggled with keeping things tweet-length on this one. Essentially, for bystanders, we have to look for multiple signals of abusive intent. If you're first-person reporting, we know you're experiencing it as abuse and don't like what's happening to you in the interaction.

@chrismessina Probably not by itself. There's lots of research that suggests confirmed, real-name identity isn't the answer to online abuse (https://t.co/7yDYfxLiJO). But making it harder for bad actors to spin up new accounts can certainly help.

@daveyalba Nothing in my thread disputes the problem ‚Äî I call it a surge in my first tweet. We have to fix this. This includes removing content, and *also* reducing its visibility at scale. Impressions have been our success measure for a long time.
@tomcoates That tweet is more than a decade old. If you need to know, it was the actual name of a Lord of the Rings-themed drag show I was at. It's not a word I'd use today.

We‚Äôre changing how we enforce these policies, but not the policies themselves, to address the gaps here.

You‚Äôll hear more from me and our teams in the days to come as we make progress. Talk is cheap; expect the data that proves we‚Äôre making meaningful improvements.

Why? Because bystanders don‚Äôt always have full context, we have a higher bar for bystander reports in order to find a violation. As a result, many reports of Tweets that in fact do violate our policies end up marked as non-violative on first review.

To try to understand the context behind potentially harmful Tweets, we treat first-person and bystander reports differently.

First person: This hateful interaction is happening to or targeting me.

Bystander: This is happening to someone else.
Many of you have said you‚Äôve reported hateful conduct and received notices saying it‚Äôs not a violation. Here‚Äôs why, and what we‚Äôre doing to fix it:

Impressions don‚Äôt tell the whole story. These issues aren‚Äôt new, and the people targeted by hateful conduct aren‚Äôt numbers or data points. We‚Äôre going to continue investing in policy and technology to make things better.

Impressions on this content typically are extremely low, platform-wide. We‚Äôre primarily dealing with a focused, short-term trolling campaign. The 1500 accounts we removed don‚Äôt correspond with 1500 people; many are repeat bad actors. https://t.co/qoMFLZJYrA

Our primary success measure for content moderation is impressions: how many times harmful content is seen by our users. The changes we‚Äôve made have almost entirely eliminated impressions on this content in search and elsewhere across Twitter. https://t.co/AnJuIu2CT6

Since Saturday, we‚Äôve been focused on addressing the surge in hateful conduct on Twitter. We‚Äôve made measurable progress, removing more than 1500 accounts and reducing impressions on this content to nearly zero. Here‚Äôs the latest on our work, and what‚Äôs next.

@C_Kavanagh @ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Yeah, I agree that there‚Äôs lots I could agree with, and I have agreed with it! For example, I think Kendi‚Äôs definition of racism, from his book, is spot on. As @ErikN_NJEdition said, my disagreements with him are mostly in his prescriptions and the reasoning therein.

@C_Kavanagh @ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod I‚Äôm not claiming to be Dr. Manhattan, I‚Äôm speaking to an ideal that I try my best to embody. I have defended and agreed with Kendi and DiAngelo, but I tend to disagree with them more overall. You can call that tribal bias, or the result of engaging with the merits of their ideas. https://t.co/f7ZC4RJ5Px

@C_Kavanagh @ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Well, I have the ideal and the fundamental value of not allowing myself to be tribal and inconsistent in that way, and that‚Äôs what I strive toward. I will fail and have failed often; I‚Äôm only human, but that‚Äôs my goal and I think it‚Äôs a worthy one.

@C_Kavanagh @ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod The *merits* of each idea are absolutely independent from the man, his goals, and his biases. It‚Äôs either true or not; it either makes sense or it doesn‚Äôt. Whether the source is a piece of shit is irrelevant to that. That‚Äôs the only point I‚Äôve been trying to make.

@C_Kavanagh @ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod I stopped listening to Bret when he stopped producing content of interest to me. I‚Äôm not just listening to everything and everyone without discernment. But I‚Äôm open to assessing something he says on its merits right now if I hear it. I have no stake in him being right or wrong.
@Sandwich_Smith Plucky, wisecracking kids that we‚Äôre supposed to identify with or find endearing but actually just annoy everybody and make the protagonist‚Äôs job harder.
@ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Yeah, that sounds about right to me.

@ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod And I think what may be important to point out here is that someone‚Äôs character/reputation may affect my judgment, but all I‚Äôm really in it for is the idea. I am not a ‚Äúfan‚Äù of people in that way. I don‚Äôt have ‚Äúgurus,‚Äù so I have no personal stake in whether they‚Äôre right or not.

@ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Yes, I think there‚Äôs a fair amount of talking past each other here as we try to parse this.

An idea is presented. I assess it on its merits. The fact that the presenter of the idea has shown poor judgment or dishonesty is something I note, but ultimately I just assess the idea.

@C_Kavanagh @ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Yeah, I never said otherwise. But I still do think the merits of the idea itself take precedent over whatever judgments I have of the source.

@CarlosCMTF @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod It has gradually become the norm throughout history‚Äîthat‚Äôs what modern civilization is. There is still war and violence, but far less than there was in the past, and the trend keeps going in that direction.

@CarlosCMTF @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod I‚Äôd prefer someone sincerely orient their behavior towards doing good in the world and be called naive or self-important for it (however true that may be about them), than not. Of course I don‚Äôt think Lex will stop the war; all I‚Äôve been saying is I appreciate where his heart is.
@Egypxican @CarlosCMTF @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Always try.

@C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod No, I don‚Äôt. I just acknowledge that despite the past, Bret may not be wrong in this case, and it‚Äôs important for me not to allow his past to totally bias my assessment. If what he‚Äôs saying makes sense, I have no problem accepting that.

@ErikN_NJEdition @Egypxican @C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Yeah, I agree with this. I never said the source doesn‚Äôt matter, only that it doesn‚Äôt matter as much as the merits of the statement itself.
@shutter_j I've already got #1, and I have watched enough movies to know #3 is nothing but trouble, so this question is actually really easy.

@C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod At the end of the day, my thing is: Does this idea make sense or not? The answer to that isn't and shouldn't be affected by the source of the idea in question.

@C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod To clarify, I agree that the source matters to a point‚Äîand that if the source has a history of being unreliable for one reason or another, that factors into my assessment of the idea. But that in itself is also a bias that needs checking, because even a broken clock and all that.
@C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Yeah, if someone has a history of dishonesty, I'd definitely note that going forward.

@C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Yeah, of course one should consider the biases involved, but to me that's part of the process of assessing a given idea, not a separate thing. @C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod Well yeah, he was clearly lying and that was discovered, so I would recognize the lies for what they are/were. @C_Kavanagh @_Apost8 @Egypxican @JohnRWoodJr @lexfridman @GurusPod I'm sure his worldview informs his approach and his conclusions, as is the case with us all. 32) Anyway -- none of that matters now.

What matters is doing the best I can.

And doing everything I can for FTX's customers.

31) And in the future, I'm going to care less about the dumb, contentless, "good actor" framework.

What matters is what you do--is *actually* doing good or bad, not just *talking* about doing good or *using ESG language*.
30) (Some of what I said was thoughtless or overly strong--I was venting and not intending that to be public.  I guess at this point what I write leaks anyway.)

29) Which means that interacting with regulatory structures can be really frustrating: a *huge* amount of work--much of it arbitrary--and relatively little customer protection.

Fuck that.  You all deserve frameworks that let regulators protect customers while allowing freedom.

28) Even so, there are regulators who have deeply impressed me with their knowledge and thoughtfulness.  The CFTC has; the SCB, and VARA, too.  And others, scattered.

But most are overwhelmed.

27) A few thoughts:

a) It's *really* hard to be a regulator.  They have an impossible job: to regulate entire industries that grow faster than their mandate allows them to.

And so often they end up mostly unable to police as well as they ideally would.

26) Well, that gives some color, I guess.

It sucks.  I'm really sorry that things ended up as they did.  And as I said--I'm going to do everything I can to make it more right.

25) Last night I talked to a friend of mine.

24) Shrapnel

23) Roughly 25% of customer assets were withdrawn each day--$4b.

As it turned out, I was wrong: leverage wasn't ~$5b, it was ~$13b.

$13b leverage, total run on the bank, total collapse in asset value, all at once.

Which is why you don't want that leverage.

---

22) And that risk was correlated--with the other collateral, and with the platform.

And then the crash came.

In a few day period, there was a historic crash--over 50% in most correlated assets, with no bid side liquidity.

And at the same time there was a run on the bank.

21) And problems were brewing.  Larger than I realized.

[AGAIN THESE NUMBERS ARE APPROXIMATE, TO THE BEST OF MY KNOWLEDGE, ETC.]

Leverage built up-- ~$5b of leverage, backed by ~$20b of assets which were....

Well, they had value.  FTT had value, in EV!  But they had risk.

20) I was on the cover of every magazine, and FTX was the darling of Silicon Valley.

We got overconfident and careless.

19) Once upon a time--a month ago--FTX was a valuable enterprise.

FTX had ~$10-15b of daily volume, and roughly $1b of annual revenue.  $40b of equity value.

And we were held as paragons of running an effective company.
18) Truth and Beauty

17) I know you've all seen this, but here's where things stand today, roughly speaking.  [LOTS OF CAVEATS, ETC.]

Liquid: -$8b
Semi: +$5.5b
Illiquid: +$3.5b

And yeah, maybe that $9b illiquid M2M isn't worth $9b (+$1b net).

OTOH--a month ago it was worth $18b; +$10b net.

---

16) Maybe I'll fail.  Maybe I won't get anything more for customers than what's already there.

I've certainly failed before.  You all know that now, all too well.

But all I can do is to try.  I've failed enough for the month.

And part of me thinks I might get somewhere.

15) A few weeks ago, FTX was handling ~$10b/day of volume and billions of transfers.

But there was too much leverage--more than I realized.  A run on the bank and market crash exhausted liquidity.

So what can I try to do?  Raise liquidity, make customers whole, and restart.

14) My goal:

a) Clean up and focus on transparency
b) Make customers whole

13) My goal‚Äîmy one goal‚Äîis to do right by customers.

I‚Äôm contributing what I can to doing so.  I‚Äôm meeting in-person with regulators and working with the teams to do what we can for customers.

And after that, investors.  But first, customers.

12) To the best of my knowledge, as of post-11/7, with the potential for errors:

a) Alameda had more assets than liabilities M2M (but not liquid!)
b) Alameda had margin position on FTX Intl
c) FTX US had enough to repay all customers

Not everyone necessarily agrees with this
11) I'll get to what happened.  But for now, let's talk about where we are today.

5) I'm piecing together all of the details, but I was shocked to see things unravel the way they did earlier this week.

I will, soon, write up a more complete post on the play by play, but I want to make sure that I get it right when I do.
4) I'm going to work on giving clarity on where things are in terms of user recovery ASAP.

3) This doesn't necessarily have to mean the end for the companies or their ability to provide value and funds to their customers chiefly, and can be consistent with other routes.

2) I'm really sorry, again, that we ended up here.

Hopefully things can find a way to recover.  Hopefully this can bring some amount of transparency, trust, and governance to them.

Ultimately hopefully it can be better for customers.

well played; you won.

18) But all of that isn't what matters right now--what matters right now is trying to do right by customers.  That's it.

Solely trust.

16) Second, in any scenario in which FTX continues operating, its first priority will be radical transparency--transparency it probably always should have been giving.

Giving as close to on-chain transparency as it can: so that people know  *exactly* what is happening on it.

15) First, one way or another, Alameda Research is winding down trading.

14) So, what does this mean going forward?

I'm not sure--that depends on what happens over the next week.

But here are some things I know.

13) Because at the end of the day, I was CEO, which means that *I* was responsible for making sure that things went well.  *I*, ultimately, should have been on top of everything.

I clearly failed in that.  I'm sorry.

12) Every penny of that--and of the existing collateral--will go straight to users, unless or until we've done right by them.

11) There are a number of players who we are in talks with, LOIs, term sheets, etc.

10) So, right now, we're spending the week doing everything we can to raise liquidity.

9) Anyway: right now, my #1 priority--by far--is doing right by users.

And I'm going to do everything I can to do that.  To take responsibility, and do what I can.

8) And so we are where we are.  Which sucks, and that's on me.

One thing, though, was clear on my visit. 

There was just one book her son was excited to read to me. 

Can you guess which one?

üêò

So what should we make of this? Can there be room for both types of books? Or do predictable readers like these encourage too many bad habits?

Imagine being my friend, the parent, who has no clue. 

What should she do with her son? She doesn‚Äôt know. https://t.co/K0sXyaTz7M

When teachers use books like this, they‚Äôre typically more focused on whether a child UNDERSTANDS the story than if they can DECODE it. 

Decoding may be part of it, but it is not the main goal. https://t.co/RxP5QMNpQD

Here‚Äôs another book he came home with. 

This, like the bug book, has words a beginning kindergartener wouldn‚Äôt be able to sound out. And again, he‚Äôs being encouraged to read based on pictures. https://t.co/47tFR7i0P4

Compare. 

See how, in the bug book, an early reader would need to know more complex phonics rules to sound out leaf or flower? That‚Äôs why a kid would turn to pictures (esp if they‚Äôre being encouraged to!) https://t.co/t1A17MSxuh

Go, Pam! is a decodable reader. 

The book is meant for readers practicing the short a sound. 

Yes, there are pictures. But a beginning reader who‚Äôs learning initial phonics rules could approach these words with confidence. They would be advised to ‚Äúsound it out.‚Äù https://t.co/W2zESXvVL4
Now let‚Äôs take a look at Go, Pam! https://t.co/SirIjDg40i

This is considered to be part of a teaching strategy  called ‚Äú3 cueing.‚Äù

The strategy, associated with balanced literacy, is under national scrutiny. https://t.co/Mm8Ia0PRNW

The second thing you‚Äôll notice are the labels on the illustrations. 

This is explicitly encouraging a child to look at a picture when they come across an unknown word. 
 
This is the habit of a poor reader, research has shown. https://t.co/ntbQiZj4kR

Critics say predictable readers don‚Äôt teach children to read ‚Äî but instead teach them to memorize. 

‚ÄúThis bug is on‚Ä¶This bug is on‚Ä¶This bug is on‚Ä¶‚Äù https://t.co/WgWlZzImHM

Let‚Äôs start with Look for Bugs. 

There are two things going on here. 

First, you‚Äôll notice the sentences repeat throughout the story, except for the last word. 

This is called a predictable reader. https://t.co/lLooR5s4tc

They both have colorful illustrations and the titles both feel age appropriate for very early readers. 

But that‚Äôs where their similarities end. 

Their differences are important. Because they illustrate a critical piece of the Science of Reading debate. https://t.co/RmKUXJ04k6

üßµ A tale of two books. 

I visited a friend over the weekend. Her son is in kindergarten. 

He brought each of these books home from school. https://t.co/5IFbd5dwZQ

There's a chaotic personality type that loves the way twitter functions as an anti-consensus machine. 

But this dynamic doesn't just dissolve bad consensus, it dissolves all consensus and all effort to converge on truth.

The issue is that all else being equal, highly differentiated content is likely to overperform because it suffers less from crowding ‚Äî but something is more likely to be highly differentiated if it's wrong.

I think it‚Äôs totally fine to prefer @elonmusk‚Äôs editorial taste to the Old Regime‚Äôs taste ‚Äî you expect a change in ownership to entail a change in editorial taste. 

But you should have some questions as to why the new boss is making this out to be about something else.

Musk‚Äôs own preferred approach to content moderation is specifically to throttle disfavored accounts, exactly what Old Regime Twitter did. 

I assume his team will have a different take on which specific accounts deserve to be de-amplified. It‚Äôs his platform so be it. https://t.co/14qc3hMBbY

It was very interesting of @elonmusk and @bariweiss to pull back the curtain on the user interface and some of the process. But what I‚Äôd really like is fuller data ‚Äî how were foreign government requests handled? How many people were flagged for de-amplification? Who exactly?

I think it‚Äôs fair to say that most people who complained about ‚Äúshadowbanning‚Äù were complaining about what Twitter actually *did* do, not about this other thing that Twitter called ‚Äúshadowbanning.‚Äù 

But there‚Äôs not some official definition we can appeal to for resolution.

To ‚Äúshadow ban‚Äù is obviously not a term with a firmly established legal definition but when Old Regime Twitter officially denied shadowbanning they offered a specific, narrowly framed definition that seems consistent with New Regime Twitter‚Äôs revelations. https://t.co/wk382lDwzS

There are true 1A idealists, but it's a tiny number, and not at all why we have a heated free-speech discourse.

Consider how the ACLU and other 1A orgs, along with journalists themselves, flipped their views on unalloyed free speech as soon as it was no longer a weapon against the right, but against the left instead. Suddenly you had pro-censorship journalists and academics.

The blackpill on liberalism and abstract rights like free speech is they're rarely promoted out of high-minded ideals, but as yet another political and narrative tool in status contests and power struggles among elites.

@spakhm What's more, Google now agrees we should be in that world. 

The same Google that once pushed back on changing results for China.

@mattbilinsky We need ever more content moderation to battle ever more disinformation. It's a forever war for truth, Matt.

Every industry, especially niche but important ones like datacenter design or pharma patent law, has some leading guru figure who gets paid a fortune, everyone wants to work with, and who leads a charmed life of $2000/hour meetings between stays at their house in Puglia.

Recall the startup truism: what seem like technical problems are often human problems, which are harder to solve.

There is no 'fix' here, no censorship or algorithmic tweak that will return us to a Golden Age of Truth. We have to adapt to our creations, as we always have.
I'm happy to have returned to the world of tech where you're paid to get things right, rather than media, where you're paid to be reliably and entertainingly wrong. https://t.co/IuBrUqPruT

The content moderation grifters will soon move on to AI as the next cow they're going to milk for cushy bullshit jobs and serious-sounding studies around how people like them need to have a seat at a table they're otherwise not part of and not particularly welcome at.

Is the public forum saner now? Is there more capital 'T' Truth online? Are we less politically divided? Is everyone safer from the supposed dangers presented by social media?

'Real content moderation has never been tried!' replies the disinformation expert. And on it goes.

Is it a wonder that those who most pushed for this content moderation regime were precisely those academics and journalists who'd never spent a day working inside such platforms, or that a cottage industry of grift would sprout like mushrooms around the resulting power center?

Putting the de facto Supreme Court of free speech inside a closed-door conference room would inevitably devolve into a corporate 'Star Chamber' beyond any judicial or democratic oversight. It was a dumb idea then, and even dumber now given the timeline.

https://t.co/LoP2AWoCyf

Which is *exactly* what happened. The Twitter files show a management overwhelmed by adjudicating every issue under the sun, and indecisive both in applying and crafting policy in an ever-changing mediascape with no set rules, while also being swayed by political biases.

But since FTX was the union of worsts--the obscurity of centralized finance but the lack of regulation and oversight of crypto--SBF was able to get away with a massive fraud that couldn't have happened in traditional finance, or in fully decentralized finance.

The tl;dr for non-crypto normies: if FTX had actually been a fully crypto-style decentralized exchange, this implosion would have been caught far earlier, as somebody snooping around Dune (a blockchain query engine) would have easily spotted the shenanigans and raised a stink.

The real question (and indictment of crypto) is why the centralized versions of everything manage to get most of the consumer adoption, while the full-blown versions struggle to gain broader adoption.

It's interesting FTX is being held up as emblematic of the ecosystem, when technologically it's just a normie Web 2 online casino that happened to trade crypto-assets.

Seems a subtle distinction, but it's not as the fully decentralized version of the above stayed unaffected.

If only we'd invented some way of easily creating financial accounts--let's call them 'wallets'--as well as a publicly-visible ledger of transfers, so that both oversight and accounting would be easy and transparent.

They needn‚Äôt be berated or publicly called out. But hard conversations need to be had by folks in positions to have them (leadership).

And people with that aim are not primarily concerned that kids develop certain competencies to become fully functioning adults.

They‚Äôre committing  edugenic harm and it should be addressed by people who know better.

She pushes that because she believes that anything from the dominant culture is wrong in some cosmic, pseudo-religious, sense. 

When I say she‚Äôs lost the plot, I mean that her aim is not student learning. It‚Äôs something else. It‚Äôs decolonization or some related idea.

Is that method of counting intrinsically True or the universal ‚Äúbest‚Äù way? 

Of course not. 

But that teacher wasn‚Äôt making a pedagogical choice in an effort to develop number sense.

But when you‚Äôre trying to teach number sense and you and your students live in a culture that counts in a particular way ‚Äì and you care about the kids actually learning number sense ‚Äì you should stick to that way.

Do other cultures count on their fingers in different ways? 

Yes. And it‚Äôs really interesting.

Of course we should fix systemic problems where possible. But much of that is outside of their control. So the message has to be that they have the power to improve their lives by the decisions that they make and how they respond to setbacks.
If we want our kids to feel empowered, and not slip into nihilism, then those of us who work with young people can't embrace a worldview that tells a hopeless story about their lives.

The implicit, or sometimes explicit, message that that which causes your life to be bad is out of your control and can only improve if enough ppl decide to upend the current systems, is incredibly disempowering (and not true).
This is why I'm concerned with the rhetoric on the left, especially to young people.

In Stoicism the ability to locate and focus on what you can control, and not worrying about the rest, is key to living a meaningful, happy, life. 

A tremendous amount of misery stems from worrying about that which is out of our control ‚Äì or trying to control it.

Policy Director Nick Pickles is asked if they should say Twitter detects ‚Äúmisinfo‚Äù through ‚ÄúML, human review, and **partnerships with outside experts?*‚Äù The employee asks, ‚ÄúI know that‚Äôs been a slippery process‚Ä¶ not sure if you want our public explanation to hang on that.‚Äù https://t.co/JEICGRTyz7

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 17.  During this time, executives were also clearly liaising with federal enforcement and intelligence agencies about moderation of election-related content. While we‚Äôre still at the start of reviewing the #TwitterFiles, we‚Äôre finding out more about these interactions every day.

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 16.  The latter group were a high-speed Supreme Court of moderation, issuing content rulings on the fly, often in minutes and based on guesses, gut calls, even Google searches, even in cases involving the President. https://t.co/5ihsPCVo62

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 15.  There was at least some tension between Safety Operations ‚Äì a larger department whose staffers used a more rules-based process for addressing issues like porn, scams, and threats ‚Äì and a smaller, more powerful cadre of senior policy execs like Roth and Gadde.

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 14.  On October 8th, 2020, executives opened a channel called ‚Äúus2020_xfn_enforcement.‚Äù Through J6, this would be home for discussions about election-related removals, especially ones that involved ‚Äúhigh-profile‚Äù accounts (often called ‚ÄúVITs‚Äù or ‚ÄúVery Important Tweeters‚Äù). https://t.co/xH29h4cYt9
@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 13.  One particular slack channel offers an unique window into the evolving thinking of top officials in late 2020 and early 2021.

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 12.  These initial reports are based on searches for docs linked to prominent executives, whose names are already public. They include Roth, former trust and policy chief Vijaya Gadde, and recently plank-walked Deputy General Counsel (and former top FBI lawyer) Jim Baker.

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 11.  After J6, internal Slacks show Twitter executives getting a kick out of intensified relationships with federal agencies. Here‚Äôs Trust and Safety head Yoel Roth, lamenting a lack of ‚Äúgeneric enough‚Äù calendar descriptions to concealing his ‚Äúvery interesting‚Äù meeting partners. https://t.co/kgC4eGykcO

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 10.  As the election approached, senior executives ‚Äì perhaps under pressure from federal agencies, with whom they met more as time progressed ‚Äì increasingly struggled with rules, and began to speak of ‚Äúvios‚Äù as pretexts to do what they‚Äôd likely have done anyway.

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 9. Before J6, Twitter was a unique mix of automated, rules-based enforcement, and more subjective moderation by senior executives. As @BariWeiss reported, the firm had a vast array of tools for manipulating visibility, most all of which were thrown at Trump (and others) pre-J6.

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 8. The bulk of the internal debate leading to Trump‚Äôs ban took place in those three January days. However, the intellectual framework was laid in the months preceding the Capitol riots.

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 7.     Twitter executives removed Trump in part over what one executive called the ‚Äúcontext surrounding‚Äù: actions by Trump and supporters ‚Äúover the course of the election and frankly last 4+ years.‚Äù In the end, they looked at a broad picture. But that approach can cut both ways. https://t.co/Trgvq5jmhS

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 6.     As soon as they finished banning Trump, Twitter execs started processing new power. They prepared to ban future presidents and White Houses ‚Äì perhaps even Joe Biden. The ‚Äúnew administration,‚Äù says one exec, ‚Äúwill not be suspended by Twitter unless absolutely necessary.‚Äù https://t.co/lr66YgDlGy

@ShellenbergerMD @bariweiss 5. Whatever your opinion on the decision to remove Trump that day, the internal communications at Twitter between January 6th-January 8th have clear historical import. Even Twitter‚Äôs employees understood in the moment it was a landmark moment in the annals of speech. https://t.co/tQ01n58XFc

4.     This first installment covers the period before the election through January 6th. Tomorrow, @Shellenbergermd will detail the chaos inside Twitter on January 7th. On Sunday, @BariWeiss will reveal the secret internal communications from the key date of January 8th.

3.     We‚Äôll show you what hasn‚Äôt been revealed: the erosion of standards within the company in months before J6, decisions by high-ranking executives to violate their own policies, and more, against the backdrop of ongoing, documented interaction with federal agencies.
2. The world knows much of the story of what happened between riots at the Capitol on January 6th, and the removal of President Donald Trump from Twitter on January 8th...

@bariweiss Reporters resumed searches through Twitter Files material ‚Äì a lot of it ‚Äì today. The next installment of ‚ÄúThe Twitter Files‚Äù will appear @bariweiss. Stay tuned.
@bariweiss The news that Baker was reviewing the ‚ÄúTwitter files‚Äù surprised everyone involved, to say the least. New Twitter chief Elon Musk acted quickly to ‚Äúexit‚Äù Baker Tuesday.

@bariweiss Baker is a controversial figure. He has been something of a Zelig of FBI controversies dating back to 2016, from the Steele Dossier to the Alfa-Server mess. He resigned in 2018 after an investigation into leaks to the press.
@bariweiss The first batch of files both reporters received was marked, ‚ÄúSpectra Baker Emails.‚Äù https://t.co/24a9NhjosB
@bariweiss ‚ÄúMy jaw hit the floor,‚Äù says Weiss.

Over the weekend, while we both dealt with obstacles to new searches, it was @BariWeiss who discovered that the person in charge of releasing the files was someone named Jim. When she called to ask ‚ÄúJim‚Äôs‚Äù last name, the answer came back: ‚ÄúJim Baker.‚Äù

The process for producing the ‚ÄúTwitter Files‚Äù involved delivery to two journalists (Bari Weiss and me) via a lawyer close to new management. However, after the initial batch, things became complicated.

We can now tell you part of the reason why. On Tuesday, Twitter Deputy General Counsel (and former FBI General Counsel) Jim Baker was fired. Among the reasons? Vetting the first batch of ‚ÄúTwitter Files‚Äù ‚Äì without knowledge of new management.
On Friday, the first installment of the Twitter files was published here. We expected to publish more over the weekend. Many wondered why there was a delay.
